column11: }); Weather Briefly: Lightning. Watch on the NOAA Weather Partners YouTube Channel

column1: Lightning is a giant spark of electricity in the atmosphere between clouds
column3: or the ground. In the early stages of development
column4: air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough
column5: this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. The flash of lightning temporarily equalizes the charged regions in the atmosphere until the opposite charges build up again.

column1: Lightning can occur between opposite charges within the thunderstorm cloud (intra-cloud lightning) or between opposite charges in the cloud and on the ground (cloud-to-ground lightning).
Lightning is one of the oldest observed natural phenomena on earth. It can be seen in volcanic eruptions
column3: surface nuclear detonations

column1: What we do: Read more about NSSL's lightning research here.
Lightning causes thunder! Energy from a lightning channel heats the air briefly to around 50
column3: much hotter than the surface of the sun. This causes the air to explode outward.  The huge pressure in the initial outward shock wave decreases rapidly with increasing distance and within ten yards or so has become small enough to be perceived as the sound we call thunder.

column1: Thunder can be heard up to 25 miles away from the lightning discharge
column2: but the frequency of the sound changes with distance from the lightning channels that produce it
column3: because higher frequencies are more quickly absorbed by the air. Very close to lightning
column4: the first thunder you hear is from the closest channels
column6: because that thunder contains high frequencies. A few seconds later
column7: you hear a sharp click or loud crack from lightning channels a little farther away
column8: and several tens of seconds later the thunder from the most distant part of a flash has quieted to low frequency rumbling.

column1: Because light travels through the air roughly a million times faster than sound does
column2: you can use thunder to estimate the distance to lightning.  Just count the number of seconds from the time you see a flash until you hear thunder.  Sound travels approximately one fifth of a mile per second or one third of a kilometer per second
column3: so dividing the number of seconds by 5 gives the number of miles to the flash and dividing by 3 gives the number of kilometers.
lightning flashes produced by storms start inside the cloud. If a lightning flash is going to strike ground
column4: a channel develops downward toward the surface. When it gets less than roughly a hundred yards of the ground
column5: objects like trees and bushes and buildings start sending up sparks to meet it.  When one of the sparks connects the downward developing channel
column6: a huge electric current surges rapidly down the channel to the object that produced the spark. Tall objects such as trees and skyscrapers are more likely than the surrounding ground to produce one of the connecting sparks and so are more likely to be struck by lightning. Mountains also make good targets. However
column7: this does not always mean tall objects will be struck. Lightning can strike the ground in an open field even if the tree line is close by.

column1: The creation of lightning is a complicated process. We generally know what conditions are needed to produce lightning
column2: but there is still debate about exactly how a cloud builds up electrical charges
column3: and how lightning forms. Scientists think that the initial process for creating charge regions in thunderstorms involves small hail particles called graupel that are roughly one quarter millimeter to a few millimeters in diameter and are growing by collecting even smaller supercooled liquid droplets.  When these graupel particles collide and bounce off of smaller ice particles
column4: the graupel gains one sign of charge and the smaller ice particle gains the other sign of charge. Because the smaller ice particles rise faster in updrafts than the graupel particles
column5: the charge on ice particles separates from the charge on graupel particles
column6: and the charge on ice particles collects above the charge on graupel.

column1: Laboratory studies suggest that graupel gains positive charge at temperatures a little colder than 32 degrees Fahrenheit
column2: but gains negative charge at colder temperatures a little higher in the storm.  Scientists think the two largest charge regions in most storms are caused mainly by graupel carrying negative charge in the middle of the storm and ice particles carrying gained positive charge in the upper part of the storm.  However
column3: a small positive charge region often is below the main negative charge region from graupel gaining positive charge at lower
column4: warmer altitudes.  Small ice particles that have collided with negative graupel in the lower region can contribute positive charge to the middle of the storm.

column1: A conceptual model shows the electrical charge distribution inside deep convection (thunderstorms)
column2: developed by NSSL and university scientists. In the main updraft (in and above the red arrow)
column3: there are four main charge regions. In the convective region but outside the outdraft (in and above the blue arrow)
column4: there are more than four charge regions.

column1: You can read more about lightning at the National Weather Service's JetStream Online School for Weather.
How is electrical charge distributed through a thunderstorm?
A conceptual model shows the electrical charge distribution inside deep convection (thunderstorms)
column2: developed by NSSL and university scientists. In the main updraft (in and above the red arrow)
column3: there are four main charge regions. In the convective region but outside the outdraft (in and above the blue arrow)
column4: there are more than four charge regions.

column1: What we do: NSSL researchers use a 3-D cloud model to investigate the full life-cycle of thunderstorms. The model has shown how graupel or other droplets could help form regions of lower charge within the storm.
NSSL team launches an instrumented weather balloon to study lightning in northern Florida.[+]

NSSL researchers were pioneers in the science of launching instrumented weather balloons into thunderstorms. This capability allowed NSSL to collect weather data in the vicinity of tornadoes and drylines
column2: and all the way up through a thunderstorm
column3: gathering critically needed observations in the near-storm environment of thunderstorms. In addition
column4: these mobile labs and ballooning systems provided the first vertical profiles of electric fields inside a thunderstorm leading to a new conceptual model of electrical structures within convective storms.

column1: One way researchers test their theories is by making measurements of severe thunderstorms in the field and later analyzing the results. Large-scale field experiments involving many instruments with a primary focus on atmospheric electricity include the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry experiment (DC3)
column2: the MCS Electrification and Polarimetric Radar Study
column3: the Severe Thunderstorm Electrification and Precipitation Study and the Thunderstorm Electrification and Lightning EXperiment.

column1: ...and skyscrapers are commonly struck by lightning.[+]
But lightning can strike the ground in an open field even if the tree line is close by. It all depends on where the charges accumulate.[+]

column1: Weather Briefly: Lightning. Watch on the NOAA Weather Partners YouTube Channel

What is lightning?
Lightning is a giant spark of electricity in the atmosphere between clouds, the air, or the ground. In the early stages of development, air acts as an insulator between the positive and negative charges in the cloud and between the cloud and the ground. When the opposite charges build up enough, this insulating capacity of the air breaks down and there is a rapid discharge of electricity that we know as lightning. The flash of lightning temporarily equalizes the charged regions in the atmosphere until the opposite charges build up again.

				    Lightning can occur between opposite charges within the thunderstorm cloud (intra-cloud lightning) or between opposite charges in the cloud and on the ground (cloud-to-ground lightning).

				    Lightning is one of the oldest observed natural phenomena on earth. It can be seen in volcanic eruptions, extremely intense forest fires, surface nuclear detonations, heavy snowstorms, in large hurricanes, and obviously, thunderstorms.				    .
What we do: Read more about NSSL's lightning research here.
What causes thunder?
Lightning causes thunder! Energy from a lightning channel heats the air briefly to around 50,000 degrees Fahrenheit, much hotter than the surface of the sun. This causes the air to explode outward.  The huge pressure in the initial outward shock wave decreases rapidly with increasing distance and within ten yards or so has become small enough to be perceived as the sound we call thunder. 

				    Thunder can be heard up to 25 miles away from the lightning discharge, but the frequency of the sound changes with distance from the lightning channels that produce it, because higher frequencies are more quickly absorbed by the air. Very close to lightning, the first thunder you hear is from the closest channels,which produce a tearing sound, because that thunder contains high frequencies. A few seconds later, you hear a sharp click or loud crack from lightning channels a little farther away, and several tens of seconds later the thunder from the most distant part of a flash has quieted to low frequency rumbling. 

				    Because light travels through the air roughly a million times faster than sound does, you can use thunder to estimate the distance to lightning.  Just count the number of seconds from the time you see a flash until you hear thunder.  Sound travels approximately one fifth of a mile per second or one third of a kilometer per second, so dividing the number of seconds by 5 gives the number of miles to the flash and dividing by 3 gives the number of kilometers.

Where does lightning strike?
Most, if not all, lightning flashes produced by storms start inside the cloud. If a lightning flash is going to strike ground, a channel develops downward toward the surface. When it gets less than roughly a hundred yards of the ground, objects like trees and bushes and buildings start sending up sparks to meet it.  When one of the sparks connects the downward developing channel, a huge electric current surges rapidly down the channel to the object that produced the spark. Tall objects such as trees and skyscrapers are more likely than the surrounding ground to produce one of the connecting sparks and so are more likely to be struck by lightning. Mountains also make good targets. However, this does not always mean tall objects will be struck. Lightning can strike the ground in an open field even if the tree line is close by.
What causes lightning?
The creation of lightning is a complicated process. We generally know what conditions are needed to produce lightning, but there is still debate about exactly how a cloud builds up electrical charges, and how lightning forms. Scientists think that the initial process for creating charge regions in thunderstorms involves small hail particles called graupel that are roughly one quarter millimeter to a few millimeters in diameter and are growing by collecting even smaller supercooled liquid droplets.  When these graupel particles collide and bounce off of smaller ice particles, the graupel gains one sign of charge and the smaller ice particle gains the other sign of charge. Because the smaller ice particles rise faster in updrafts than the graupel particles, the charge on ice particles separates from the charge on graupel particles, and the charge on ice particles collects above the charge on graupel. 

				    Laboratory studies suggest that graupel gains positive charge at temperatures a little colder than 32 degrees Fahrenheit, but gains negative charge at colder temperatures a little higher in the storm.  Scientists think the two largest charge regions in most storms are caused mainly by graupel carrying negative charge in the middle of the storm and ice particles carrying gained positive charge in the upper part of the storm.  However, a small positive charge region often is below the main negative charge region from graupel gaining positive charge at lower, warmer altitudes.  Small ice particles that have collided with negative graupel in the lower region can contribute positive charge to the middle of the storm. 

				    A conceptual model shows the electrical charge distribution inside deep convection (thunderstorms), developed by NSSL and university scientists. In the main updraft (in and above the red arrow), there are four main charge regions. In the convective region but outside the outdraft (in and above the blue arrow), there are more than four charge regions.

					You can read more about lightning at the National Weather Service's JetStream Online School for Weather.

NSSL researchers were pioneers in the science of launching instrumented weather balloons into thunderstorms. This capability allowed NSSL to collect weather data in the vicinity of tornadoes and drylines, and all the way up through a thunderstorm, gathering critically needed observations in the near-storm environment of thunderstorms. In addition, these mobile labs and ballooning systems provided the first vertical profiles of electric fields inside a thunderstorm leading to a new conceptual model of electrical structures within convective storms.

NSSL researchers were pioneers in the science of launching instrumented weather balloons into thunderstorms. This capability allowed NSSL to collect weather data in the vicinity of tornadoes and drylines, and all the way up through a thunderstorm, gathering critically needed observations in the near-storm environment of thunderstorms. In addition, these mobile labs and ballooning systems provided the first vertical profiles of electric fields inside a thunderstorm leading to a new conceptual model of electrical structures within convective storms.

One way researchers test their theories is by making measurements of severe thunderstorms in the field and later analyzing the results. Large-scale field experiments involving many instruments with a primary focus on atmospheric electricity include the Deep Convective Clouds and Chemistry experiment (DC3), the MCS Electrification and Polarimetric Radar Study, the Severe Thunderstorm Electrification and Precipitation Study and the Thunderstorm Electrification and Lightning EXperiment.

Lightning is a naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions
column2: both in the atmosphere or with one on the ground
column3: temporarily neutralize themselves
column4: causing the instantaneous release of an average of one gigajoule of energy.[1][2][3] This discharge may produce a wide range of electromagnetic radiation
column5: from heat created by the rapid movement of electrons
column6: to brilliant flashes of visible light in the form of black-body radiation. Lightning causes thunder
column7: a sound from the shock wave which develops as gases in the vicinity of the discharge experience a sudden increase in pressure. Lightning occurs commonly during thunderstorms as well as other types of energetic weather systems
column8: but volcanic lightning can also occur during volcanic eruptions.

column1: The three main kinds of lightning are distinguished by where they occur: either inside a single thundercloud
column3: or between a cloud and the ground. Many other observational variants are recognized
column5: which can be seen from a great distance but not heard; dry lightning
column6: which can cause forest fires; and ball lightning

column1: Humans have deified lightning for millennia. Idiomatic expressions derived from lightning
column2: such as the English expression "bolt from the blue"
column3: are common across languages. The fear of lightning is called astraphobia.

column1: (Figure 1) The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where the air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F).
The details of the charging process are still being studied by scientists
column2: but there is general agreement on some of the basic concepts of thunderstorm electrification. Electrification can be by the triboelectric effect as a result of ion transfer between colliding bodies. Uncharged
column3: colliding water-drops can become charged because of charge transfer between them (as aqueous ions) in an electric field as would exist in a thunder cloud.[4] The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F); see Figure 1. In that area
column4: the combination of temperature and rapid upward air movement produces a mixture of super-cooled cloud droplets (small water droplets below freezing)
column6: and graupel (soft hail). The updraft carries the super-cooled cloud droplets and very small ice crystals upward. At the same time
column8: which is considerably larger and denser
column9: tends to fall or be suspended in the rising air.[5]

column1: (Figure 2) When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged.

column1: The differences in the movement of the precipitation cause collisions to occur. When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged; see Figure 2. The updraft carries the positively charged ice crystals upward toward the top of the storm cloud. The larger and denser graupel is either suspended in the middle of the thunderstorm cloud or falls toward the lower part of the storm.[5]

column1: The upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to the lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.
The result is that the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.[5]

The upward motions within the storm and winds at higher levels in the atmosphere tend to cause the small ice crystals (and positive charge) in the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud to spread out horizontally some distance from the thunderstorm cloud base. This part of the thunderstorm cloud is called the anvil. While this is the main charging process for the thunderstorm cloud
column2: some of these charges can be redistributed by air movements within the storm (updrafts and downdrafts). In addition
column3: there is a small but important positive charge buildup near the bottom of the thunderstorm cloud due to the precipitation and warmer temperatures.[5]

column1: The induced separation of charge in pure liquid water has been known since the 1840s as has the electrification of pure liquid water by the tribo-electric effect.[6]

William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) demonstrated that charge separation in water occurs in the usual electric fields at the earth's surface and developed a continuous electric field measuring device using that knowledge.[7]

The physical separation of charge into different regions using liquid water was demonstrated by Kelvin with the Kelvin water dropper. The most likely charge-carrying species were considered to be the aqueous hydrogen ion and the aqueous hydroxide ion.[8]
The electrical charging of solid water ice has also been considered. The charged species were again considered to be the hydrogen ion and the hydroxide ion.[9][10]
An electron is not stable in liquid water with respect to a hydroxide ion plus dissolved hydrogen for the time scales involved in thunder storms.[11]

The charge carrier in lightning is mainly electrons in a plasma.[12] The process of going from charge as ions (positive hydrogen ion and negative hydroxide ion) associated with liquid water or solid water to charge as electrons associated with lightning must involve some form of electro-chemistry
column3: the oxidation and/or the reduction of chemical species.[13] As hydroxide functions as a base and carbon dioxide is an acidic gas
column4: it is possible that charged water clouds in which the negative charge is in the form of the aqueous hydroxide ion
column5: interact with atmospheric carbon dioxide to form aqueous carbonate ions and aqueous hydrogen carbonate ions.

column1: The typical cloud-to-ground lightning flash culminates in the formation of an electrically conducting plasma channel through the air in excess of 5km (3.1mi) tall
column2: from within the cloud to the ground's surface. The actual discharge is the final stage of a very complex process.[14] At its peak
column3: a typical thunderstorm produces three or more strikes to the Earth per minute.[15] Lightning primarily occurs when warm air is mixed with colder air masses
column4: [16] resulting in atmospheric disturbances necessary for polarizing the atmosphere.[citation needed] However
column5: it can also occur during dust storms
column9: and even in the cold of winter
column10: where the lightning is known as thundersnow.[17][18] Hurricanes typically generate some lightning
column11: mainly in the rainbands as much as 160km (99mi) from the center.[19][20][21]

column1: Because human beings are terrestrial and most of their possessions are on the Earth where lightning can damage or destroy them
column2: cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning is the most studied and best understood of the three types
column3: even though in-cloud (IC) and cloud-to-cloud (CC) are more common types of lightning. Lightning's relative unpredictability limits a complete explanation of how or why it occurs
column4: even after hundreds of years of scientific investigation.

column1: About 70% of lightning occurs over land in the tropics[24] where atmospheric convection is the greatest.
This occurs from both the mixture of warmer and colder air masses
column2: as well as differences in moisture concentrations
column3: and it generally happens at the boundaries between them. The flow of warm ocean currents past drier land masses
column5: partially explains the elevated frequency of lightning in the Southeast United States. Because large bodies of water lack the topographic variation that would result in atmospheric mixing
column6: lightning is notably less frequent over the world's oceans than over land. The North and South Poles are limited in their coverage of thunderstorms and therefore result in areas with the least lightning.[clarification needed]

column2: CG lightning flashes account for only 25% of all total lightning flashes worldwide. Since the base of a thunderstorm is usually negatively charged
column3: this is where most CG lightning originates. This region is typically at the elevation where freezing occurs within the cloud. Freezing
column4: combined with collisions between ice and water
column5: appears to be a critical part of the initial charge development and separation process. During wind-driven collisions
column6: ice crystals tend to develop a positive charge

column9: causing the top region of the cloud to accumulate a positive space charge while the lower level accumulates a negative space charge.

As a thundercloud moves over the surface of the Earth

Certain prominent structures often attract frequent lightning strikes. The CN Tower in Toronto is struck many times every summer.
The best-studied and understood form of lightning is cloud to ground (CG) lightning. Although more common
column2: intra-cloud (IC) and cloud-to-cloud (CC) flashes are very difficult to study given there are no "physical" points to monitor inside the clouds. Also

Lightning strike counter in a museum

The earliest detector invented to warn of the approach of a thunderstorm was the lightning bell. Benjamin Franklin installed one such device in his house.[123][124] The detector was based on an electrostatic device called the 'electric chimes' invented by Andrew Gordon in 1742.
Lightning discharges generate a wide range of electromagnetic radiations
column2: including radio-frequency pulses. The times at which a pulse from a given lightning discharge arrives at several receivers can be used to locate the source of the discharge with a precision on the order of metres. The United States federal government has constructed a nationwide grid of such lightning detectors
column3: allowing lightning discharges to be tracked in real time throughout the continental U.S.[125][126]

column2: a private global detection system that consists of over 500 detection stations owned and operated by hobbyists/volunteers provides near real-time lightning maps at blitzortung.org

column1: The Earth-ionosphere waveguide traps electromagnetic VLF- and ELF waves. Electromagnetic pulses transmitted by lightning strikes propagate within that waveguide. The waveguide is dispersive
column2: which means that their group velocity depends on frequency. The difference of the group time delay of a lightning pulse at adjacent frequencies is proportional to the distance between transmitter and receiver. Together with direction-finding methods
column3: this allows locating lightning strikes up to distances of 10
column5: the eigenfrequencies of the Earth-ionospheric waveguide

column2: are used to determine the global thunderstorm activity.[127]

column1: In addition to ground-based lightning detection
column2: several instruments aboard satellites have been constructed to observe lightning distribution. These include the Optical Transient Detector (OTD)
column3: aboard the OrbView-1 satellite launched on April 3
column5: and the subsequent Lightning Imaging Sensor (LIS) aboard TRMM launched on November 28

column2: the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration launched Geostationary Operational Environmental SatelliteR Series (GOES-R) weather satellites outfitted with Geostationary Lightning Mapper (GLM) instruments which are near-infrared optical transient detectors that can detect the momentary changes in an optical scene
column3: indicating the presence of lightning.[131][132] The lighting detection data can be converted into a real-time map of lightning activity across the Western Hemisphere; this mapping technique has been implemented by the United States National Weather Service.[133]

column1: Rocket-triggered lightning can be "triggered" by launching specially designed rockets trailing spools of wire into thunderstorms. The wire unwinds as the rocket ascends
column2: creating an elevated ground that can attract descending leaders. If a leader attaches
column3: the wire provides a low-resistance pathway for a lightning flash to occur. The wire is vaporized by the return current flow
column4: creating a straight lightning plasma channel in its place. This method allows for scientific research of lightning to occur under a more controlled and predictable manner.[134]

column1: The International Center for Lightning Research and Testing (ICLRT) at Camp Blanding
column2: Florida typically uses rocket triggered lightning in their research studies.
[135] researchers have attempted to trigger lightning strikes by means of infrared or ultraviolet lasers
column3: which create a channel of ionized gas through which the lightning would be conducted to ground. Such triggering of lightning is intended to protect rocket launching pads

scientists tested a new terawatt laser which provoked lightning. Scientists fired ultra-fast pulses from an extremely powerful laser thus sending several terawatts into the clouds to call down electrical discharges in storm clouds over the region. The laser beams sent from the laser make channels of ionized molecules known as filaments. Before the lightning strikes earth
column4: the filaments lead electricity through the clouds
column5: playing the role of lightning rods. Researchers generated filaments that lived a period too short to trigger a real lightning strike. Nevertheless
column6: a boost in electrical activity within the clouds was registered. According to the French and German scientists who ran the experiment
column7: the fast pulses sent from the laser will be able to provoke lightning strikes on demand.[141] Statistical analysis showed that their laser pulses indeed enhanced the electrical activity in the thundercloud where it was aimedin effect they generated small local discharges located at the position of the plasma channels.[142]

column1: Lightning-induced remanent magnetization (LIRM) mapped during a magnetic field gradient survey of an archaeological site located in Wyoming

The movement of electrical charges produces a magnetic field (see electromagnetism). The intense currents of a lightning discharge create a fleeting but very strong magnetic field. Where the lightning current path passes through rock
column3: or metal these materials can become permanently magnetized. This effect is known as lightning-induced remanent magnetism
column4: or LIRM. These currents follow the least resistive path
column5: often horizontally near the surface[143][144] but sometimes vertically
column8: or ground water offers a less resistive path.[145] One theory suggests that lodestones
column9: natural magnets encountered in ancient times

column1: Lightning-induced magnetic anomalies can be mapped in the ground
column2: [147][148] and analysis of magnetized materials can confirm lightning was the source of the magnetization[149] and provide an estimate of the peak current of the lightning discharge.[150]

column1: Research at the University of Innsbruck has found that magnetic fields generated by plasma may induce hallucinations in subjects located within 200m (660ft) of a severe lightning storm.[151]
Some high energy cosmic rays produced by supernovas as well as solar particles from the solar wind
column2: enter the atmosphere and electrify the air
column3: which may create pathways for lightning bolts.[152]

column1: Due to the low resolution of global climate models
column2: accurately representing lightning in these climate models is difficult
column3: largely due to their inability to simulate the convection and cloud ice imperative which are fundamental to lightning formation. Research from the Future Climate for Africa programme demonstrates that using a convection-permitting model over Africa can more accurately capture convective thunderstorms and the distribution of ice particles. This research indicates climate change may increase the total amount of lightning only slightly: the total number of lightning days per year decreases
column4: while more cloud ice and stronger convection leads to more lightning strikes occurring on days when lightning does occur.[153]

column1: A study from the University of Washington looked at lightning activity in the Arctic from 2010 to 2020. The ratio of Arctic summertime strokes was compared to total global strokes and was observed to be increasing with time
column2: indicating that the region is becoming more influenced by lightning. The fraction of strokes above 65 degrees north was found to be increasing linearly with the NOAA global temperature anomaly and grew by a factor of 3 as the anomaly increased from 0.65 to 0.95C [154]

column1: .mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}These paragraphs are an excerpt from Paleolightning.[edit]
Paleolightning refers to the remnants of ancient lightning activity studied in fields such as historical geology
column3: and fulminology. Paleolightning provides tangible evidence for the study lightning activity in Earth's past and the roles lightning may have played in Earth's history. Some studies have speculated that lightning activity played a crucial role in the development of not only Earth's early atmosphere but also early life. Lightning
column5: has been found to produce biologically useful material through the oxidation and reduction of inorganic matter.[155] Research on the impact of lightning on Earth's atmosphere continues today
column6: especially with regard to feedback mechanisms of lightning-produced nitrate compounds on atmospheric composition and global average temperatures.[156]

column1: Detecting lightning activity in the geologic record can be difficult
column2: given the instantaneous nature of lightning strikes in general. However
column3: fulgurite
column6: or irregular mineraloid that forms when lightning fuses soil
column11: or caliche is prevalent in electrically-active regions around the globe and provides evidence of not only past lightning activity
column12: but also patterns of convection.[157]  Since lightning channels carry an electric current to the ground
column13: lightning can produce magnetic fields as well. While lightning-magnetic anomalies can provide evidence of lightning activity in a region
column14: these anomalies are often problematic for those examining the magnetic record of rock types because they disguise the natural magnetic fields present.[158]

column2: lightning has been viewed as part of a deity or a deity in and of itself. These include the Greek god Zeus
column3: the Aztec god Tlaloc
column11: and the Shinto god Raijin.[159] In the traditional religion of the African Bantu tribes
column12: lightning is a sign of the ire of the gods. Verses in the Jewish religion and in Islam also ascribe supernatural importance to lightning. In Christianity
column13: the Second Coming of Jesus is compared to lightning.[Matthew 24:27][Luke 17:24]

column1: The expression "Lightning never strikes twice (in the same place)" is similar to "Opportunity never knocks twice" in the vein of a "once in a lifetime" opportunity
column3: something that is generally considered improbable. Lightning occurs frequently and more so in specific areas. Since various factors alter the probability of strikes at any given location
column4: repeat lightning strikes have a very low probability (but are not impossible).[160][161] Similarly
column5: "A bolt from the blue" refers to something totally unexpected
column6: and "A person being struck by lightning" is an imaginative or comedic metaphor for someone to experience a once in a lifetime
column9: similar to an epiphany or an enlightenment.

column2: the expression for "Love at first sight" is coup de foudre and colpo di fulmine
column3: respectively
column4: which literally translated means "lightning strike". Some European languages have a separate word for lightning which strikes the ground (as opposed to lightning in general); often it is a cognate of the English word "rays". The name of Australia's most celebrated thoroughbred horse
column6: derives from the shared Zhuang and Thai word for lightning.[162]

column1: Two lightning bolts pictured in the former coat of arms of the Yli-Ii municipality
The bolt of lightning in heraldry is called a thunderbolt and is shown as a zigzag with non-pointed ends. This symbol usually represents power and speed.
Some political parties use lightning flashes as a symbol of power
column2: such as the People's Action Party in Singapore
column3: the British Union of Fascists during the 1930s
column4: and the National States' Rights Party in the United States during the 1950s.[163] The Schutzstaffel
column5: the paramilitary wing of the Nazi Party
column6: used the Sig rune in their logo which symbolizes lightning. The German word Blitzkrieg
column8: was a major offensive strategy of the German army during World War II.

column1: The lightning bolt is a common insignia for military communications units throughout the world. A lightning bolt is also the NATO symbol for a signal asset.
The lightning bolt is used to represent the instantaneous communication capabilities of electrically powered telegraphs and radios. It was a commonly used motif in Art Deco design
column2: especially the zig-zag Art Deco design of the late 1920s.[164]

column1: Lightning is a naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions
column2: both in the atmosphere or with one on the ground
column3: temporarily neutralize themselves
column4: causing the instantaneous release of an average of one gigajoule of energy.[1][2][3] This discharge may produce a wide range of electromagnetic radiation
column5: from heat created by the rapid movement of electrons
column6: to brilliant flashes of visible light in the form of black-body radiation. Lightning causes thunder
column7: a sound from the shock wave which develops as gases in the vicinity of the discharge experience a sudden increase in pressure. Lightning occurs commonly during thunderstorms as well as other types of energetic weather systems
column8: but volcanic lightning can also occur during volcanic eruptions.

column1: The three main kinds of lightning are distinguished by where they occur: either inside a single thundercloud
column3: or between a cloud and the ground. Many other observational variants are recognized
column5: which can be seen from a great distance but not heard; dry lightning
column6: which can cause forest fires; and ball lightning

column1: Humans have deified lightning for millennia. Idiomatic expressions derived from lightning
column2: such as the English expression "bolt from the blue"
column3: are common across languages. The fear of lightning is called astraphobia.

column1: (Figure 1) The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where the air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F).
The details of the charging process are still being studied by scientists
column2: but there is general agreement on some of the basic concepts of thunderstorm electrification. Electrification can be by the triboelectric effect as a result of ion transfer between colliding bodies. Uncharged
column3: colliding water-drops can become charged because of charge transfer between them (as aqueous ions) in an electric field as would exist in a thunder cloud.[4] The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F); see Figure 1. In that area
column4: the combination of temperature and rapid upward air movement produces a mixture of super-cooled cloud droplets (small water droplets below freezing)
column6: and graupel (soft hail). The updraft carries the super-cooled cloud droplets and very small ice crystals upward. At the same time
column8: which is considerably larger and denser
column9: tends to fall or be suspended in the rising air.[5]

column1: (Figure 2) When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged.

column1: The differences in the movement of the precipitation cause collisions to occur. When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged; see Figure 2. The updraft carries the positively charged ice crystals upward toward the top of the storm cloud. The larger and denser graupel is either suspended in the middle of the thunderstorm cloud or falls toward the lower part of the storm.[5]

column1: The upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to the lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.
The result is that the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.[5]

The upward motions within the storm and winds at higher levels in the atmosphere tend to cause the small ice crystals (and positive charge) in the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud to spread out horizontally some distance from the thunderstorm cloud base. This part of the thunderstorm cloud is called the anvil. While this is the main charging process for the thunderstorm cloud
column2: some of these charges can be redistributed by air movements within the storm (updrafts and downdrafts). In addition
column3: there is a small but important positive charge buildup near the bottom of the thunderstorm cloud due to the precipitation and warmer temperatures.[5]

column1: The induced separation of charge in pure liquid water has been known since the 1840s as has the electrification of pure liquid water by the tribo-electric effect.[6]

William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) demonstrated that charge separation in water occurs in the usual electric fields at the earth's surface and developed a continuous electric field measuring device using that knowledge.[7]

The physical separation of charge into different regions using liquid water was demonstrated by Kelvin with the Kelvin water dropper. The most likely charge-carrying species were considered to be the aqueous hydrogen ion and the aqueous hydroxide ion.[8]
The electrical charging of solid water ice has also been considered. The charged species were again considered to be the hydrogen ion and the hydroxide ion.[9][10]
An electron is not stable in liquid water with respect to a hydroxide ion plus dissolved hydrogen for the time scales involved in thunder storms.[11]

The charge carrier in lightning is mainly electrons in a plasma.[12] The process of going from charge as ions (positive hydrogen ion and negative hydroxide ion) associated with liquid water or solid water to charge as electrons associated with lightning must involve some form of electro-chemistry
column3: the oxidation and/or the reduction of chemical species.[13] As hydroxide functions as a base and carbon dioxide is an acidic gas
column4: it is possible that charged water clouds in which the negative charge is in the form of the aqueous hydroxide ion
column5: interact with atmospheric carbon dioxide to form aqueous carbonate ions and aqueous hydrogen carbonate ions.

column1: The typical cloud-to-ground lightning flash culminates in the formation of an electrically conducting plasma channel through the air in excess of 5km (3.1mi) tall
column2: from within the cloud to the ground's surface. The actual discharge is the final stage of a very complex process.[14] At its peak
column3: a typical thunderstorm produces three or more strikes to the Earth per minute.[15] Lightning primarily occurs when warm air is mixed with colder air masses
column4: [16] resulting in atmospheric disturbances necessary for polarizing the atmosphere.[citation needed] However
column5: it can also occur during dust storms
column9: and even in the cold of winter
column10: where the lightning is known as thundersnow.[17][18] Hurricanes typically generate some lightning
column11: mainly in the rainbands as much as 160km (99mi) from the center.[19][20][21]

column1: Because human beings are terrestrial and most of their possessions are on the Earth where lightning can damage or destroy them
column2: cloud-to-ground (CG) lightning is the most studied and best understood of the three types
column3: even though in-cloud (IC) and cloud-to-cloud (CC) are more common types of lightning. Lightning's relative unpredictability limits a complete explanation of how or why it occurs
column4: even after hundreds of years of scientific investigation.

column1: About 70% of lightning occurs over land in the tropics[24] where atmospheric convection is the greatest.
This occurs from both the mixture of warmer and colder air masses
column2: as well as differences in moisture concentrations
column3: and it generally happens at the boundaries between them. The flow of warm ocean currents past drier land masses
column5: partially explains the elevated frequency of lightning in the Southeast United States. Because large bodies of water lack the topographic variation that would result in atmospheric mixing
column6: lightning is notably less frequent over the world's oceans than over land. The North and South Poles are limited in their coverage of thunderstorms and therefore result in areas with the least lightning.[clarification needed]

column2: CG lightning flashes account for only 25% of all total lightning flashes worldwide. Since the base of a thunderstorm is usually negatively charged
column3: this is where most CG lightning originates. This region is typically at the elevation where freezing occurs within the cloud. Freezing
column4: combined with collisions between ice and water
column5: appears to be a critical part of the initial charge development and separation process. During wind-driven collisions
column6: ice crystals tend to develop a positive charge
column8: slushy mixture of ice and water (called graupel) develops a negative charge. Updrafts within a storm cloud separate the lighter ice crystals from the heavier graupel
column9: causing the top region of the cloud to accumulate a positive space charge while the lower level accumulates a negative space charge.

column1: Because the concentrated charge within the cloud must exceed the insulating properties of air
column2: and this increases proportionally to the distance between the cloud and the ground
column3: the proportion of CG strikes (versus CC or IC discharges) becomes greater when the cloud is closer to the ground. In the tropics
column4: where the freezing level is generally higher in the atmosphere
column5: only 10% of lightning flashes are CG. At the latitude of Norway (around 60 North latitude)

column1: Lightning is usually produced by cumulonimbus clouds
column2: which have bases that are typically 12km (0.621.24mi) above the ground and tops up to 15km (9.3mi) in height.

Certain prominent structures often attract frequent lightning strikes. The CN Tower in Toronto is struck many times every summer.
The best-studied and understood form of lightning is cloud to ground (CG) lightning. Although more common

column1: In a process not well understood
column2: a bidirectional channel of ionized air
column3: called a "leader"
column4: is initiated between oppositely-charged regions in a thundercloud. Leaders are electrically conductive channels of ionized gas that propagate through
column6: regions with a charge opposite of that of the leader tip. The negative end of the bidirectional leader fills a positive charge region
column8: inside the cloud while the positive end fills a negative charge well. Leaders often split
column9: forming branches in a tree-like pattern.[36] In addition
column10: negative and some positive leaders travel in a discontinuous fashion
column11: in a process called "stepping". The resulting jerky movement of the leaders can be readily observed in slow-motion videos of lightning flashes.

column1: It is possible for one end of the leader to fill the oppositely-charged well entirely while the other end is still active. When this happens
column2: the leader end which filled the well may propagate outside of the thundercloud and result in either a cloud-to-air flash or a cloud-to-ground flash. In a typical cloud-to-ground flash
column3: a bidirectional leader initiates between the main negative and lower positive charge regions in a thundercloud. The weaker positive charge region is filled quickly by the negative leader which then propagates toward the inductively-charged ground.

column1: The positively and negatively charged leaders proceed in opposite directions
column2: positive upwards within the cloud and negative towards the earth. Both ionic channels proceed
column3: in their respective directions
column4: in a number of successive spurts. Each leader "pools" ions at the leading tips
column5: shooting out one or more new leaders
column6: momentarily pooling again to concentrate charged ions
column7: then shooting out another leader. The negative leader continues to propagate and split as it heads downward
column8: often speeding up as it gets closer to the Earth's surface.

column1: About 90% of ionic channel lengths between "pools" are approximately 45m (148ft) in length.[37] The establishment of the ionic channel takes a comparatively long amount of time (hundreds of milliseconds) in comparison to the resulting discharge
column2: which occurs within a few dozen microseconds. The electric current needed to establish the channel
column3: measured in the tens or hundreds of amperes
column4: is dwarfed by subsequent currents during the actual discharge.

column1: Initiation of the lightning leader is not well understood. The electric field strength within the thundercloud is not typically large enough to initiate this process by itself.[38] Many hypotheses have been proposed. One hypothesis postulates that showers of relativistic electrons are created by cosmic rays and are then accelerated to higher velocities via a process called runaway breakdown. As these relativistic electrons collide and ionize neutral air molecules
column2: they initiate leader formation. Another hypothesis involves locally enhanced electric fields being formed near elongated water droplets or ice crystals.[39] Percolation theory
column3: especially for the case of biased percolation

Scientists fired ultra-fast pulses from an extremely powerful laser thus sending several terawatts into the clouds to call down electrical discharges in storm clouds over the region. The laser beams sent from the laser make channels of ionized molecules known as filaments. Before the lightning strikes earth
column4: the filaments lead electricity through the clouds
column5: playing the role of lightning rods. Researchers generated filaments that lived a period too short to trigger a real lightning strike. Nevertheless
column6: a boost in electrical activity within the clouds was registered. According to the French and German scientists who ran the experiment
column7: the fast pulses sent from the laser will be able to provoke lightning strikes on demand.[141] Statistical analysis showed that their laser pulses indeed enhanced the electrical activity in the thundercloud where it was aimedin effect they generated small local discharges located at the position of the plasma channels.[142]

column1: Lightning-induced remanent magnetization (LIRM) mapped during a magnetic field gradient survey of an archaeological site located in Wyoming

The movement of electrical charges produces a magnetic field (see electromagnetism). The intense currents of a lightning discharge create a fleeting but very strong magnetic field. Where the lightning current path passes through rock
column3: or metal these materials can become permanently magnetized. This effect is known as lightning-induced remanent magnetism
column4: or LIRM. These currents follow the least resistive path
column5: often horizontally near the surface[143][144] but sometimes vertically
column8: or ground water offers a less resistive path.[145] One theory suggests that lodestones
column9: natural magnets encountered in ancient times

column1: Lightning-induced magnetic anomalies can be mapped in the ground
column2: [147][148] and analysis of magnetized materials can confirm lightning was the source of the magnetization[149] and provide an estimate of the peak current of the lightning discharge.[150]

column1: Research at the University of Innsbruck has found that magnetic fields generated by plasma may induce hallucinations in subjects located within 200m (660ft) of a severe lightning storm.[151]
Some high energy cosmic rays produced by supernovas as well as solar particles from the solar wind
column2: enter the atmosphere and electrify the air
column3: which may create pathways for lightning bolts.[152]

column1: Due to the low resolution of global climate models
column2: accurately representing lightning in these climate models is difficult
column3: largely due to their inability to simulate the convection and cloud ice imperative which are fundamental to lightning formation. Research from the Future Climate for Africa programme demonstrates that using a convection-permitting model over Africa can more accurately capture convective thunderstorms and the distribution of ice particles. This research indicates climate change may increase the total amount of lightning only slightly: the total number of lightning days per year decreases
column4: while more cloud ice and stronger convection leads to more lightning strikes occurring on days when lightning does occur.[153]

column1: A study from the University of Washington looked at lightning activity in the Arctic from 2010 to 2020. The ratio of Arctic summertime strokes was compared to total global strokes and was observed to be increasing with time
column2: indicating that the region is becoming more influenced by lightning. The fraction of strokes above 65 degrees north was found to be increasing linearly with the NOAA global temperature anomaly and grew by a factor of 3 as the anomaly increased from 0.65 to 0.95C [154]

column1: .mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}These paragraphs are an excerpt from Paleolightning.[edit]
Paleolightning refers to the remnants of ancient lightning activity studied in fields such as historical geology
column3: and fulminology. Paleolightning provides tangible evidence for the study lightning activity in Earth's past and the roles lightning may have played in Earth's history. Some studies have speculated that lightning activity played a crucial role in the development of not only Earth's early atmosphere but also early life. Lightning
column5: has been found to produce biologically useful material through the oxidation and reduction of inorganic matter.[155] Research on the impact of lightning on Earth's atmosphere continues today
column6: especially with regard to feedback mechanisms of lightning-produced nitrate compounds on atmospheric composition and global average temperatures.[156]

column1: Detecting lightning activity in the geologic record can be difficult
column2: given the instantaneous nature of lightning strikes in general. However
column3: fulgurite
column6: or irregular mineraloid that forms when lightning fuses soil
column11: or caliche is prevalent in electrically-active regions around the globe and provides evidence of not only past lightning activity
column12: but also patterns of convection.[157]  Since lightning channels carry an electric current to the ground
column13: lightning can produce magnetic fields as well. While lightning-magnetic anomalies can provide evidence of lightning activity in a region
column14: these anomalies are often problematic for those examining the magnetic record of rock types because they disguise the natural magnetic fields present.[158]

column2: lightning has been viewed as part of a deity or a deity in and of itself. These include the Greek god Zeus
column3: the Aztec god Tlaloc
column11: and the Shinto god Raijin.[159] In the traditional religion of the African Bantu tribes
column12: lightning is a sign of the ire of the gods. Verses in the Jewish religion and in Islam also ascribe supernatural importance to lightning. In Christianity
column13: the Second Coming of Jesus is compared to lightning.[Matthew 24:27][Luke 17:24]

column1: The expression "Lightning never strikes twice (in the same place)" is similar to "Opportunity never knocks twice" in the vein of a "once in a lifetime" opportunity
column3: something that is generally considered improbable. Lightning occurs frequently and more so in specific areas. Since various factors alter the probability of strikes at any given location
column4: repeat lightning strikes have a very low probability (but are not impossible).[160][161] Similarly
column5: "A bolt from the blue" refers to something totally unexpected
column6: and "A person being struck by lightning" is an imaginative or comedic metaphor for someone to experience a once in a lifetime
column9: similar to an epiphany or an enlightenment.

column2: the expression for "Love at first sight" is coup de foudre and colpo di fulmine
column3: respectively
column4: which literally translated means "lightning strike". Some European languages have a separate word for lightning which strikes the ground (as opposed to lightning in general); often it is a cognate of the English word "rays". The name of Australia's most celebrated thoroughbred horse
column6: derives from the shared Zhuang and Thai word for lightning.[162]

column1: Two lightning bolts pictured in the former coat of arms of the Yli-Ii municipality
The bolt of lightning in heraldry is called a thunderbolt and is shown as a zigzag with non-pointed ends. This symbol usually represents power and speed.
Some political parties use lightning flashes as a symbol of power
column2: such as the People's Action Party in Singapore
column3: the British Union of Fascists during the 1930s
column4: and the National States' Rights Party in the United States during the 1950s.[163] The Schutzstaffel
column5: the paramilitary wing of the Nazi Party
column6: used the Sig rune in their logo which symbolizes lightning. The German word Blitzkrieg
column8: was a major offensive strategy of the German army during World War II.

column1: The lightning bolt is a common insignia for military communications units throughout the world. A lightning bolt is also the NATO symbol for a signal asset.
The lightning bolt is used to represent the instantaneous communication capabilities of electrically powered telegraphs and radios. It was a commonly used motif in Art Deco design
column2: especially the zig-zag Art Deco design of the late 1920s.[164]

Lightning is a naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions
column2: both in the atmosphere or with one on the ground
column3: temporarily neutralize themselves
column4: causing the instantaneous release of an average of one gigajoule of energy.[1][2][3] This discharge may produce a wide range of electromagnetic radiation
column5: from heat created by the rapid movement of electrons
column6: to brilliant flashes of visible light in the form of black-body radiation. Lightning causes thunder
column7: a sound from the shock wave which develops as gases in the vicinity of the discharge experience a sudden increase in pressure. Lightning occurs commonly during thunderstorms as well as other types of energetic weather systems
column8: but volcanic lightning can also occur during volcanic eruptions.

column1: The three main kinds of lightning are distinguished by where they occur: either inside a single thundercloud
column3: or between a cloud and the ground. Many other observational variants are recognized
column5: which can be seen from a great distance but not heard; dry lightning
column6: which can cause forest fires; and ball lightning

column1: Humans have deified lightning for millennia. Idiomatic expressions derived from lightning
column2: such as the English expression "bolt from the blue"
column3: are common across languages. The fear of lightning is called astraphobia.

column1: (Figure 1) The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where the air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F).
The details of the charging process are still being studied by scientists
column2: but there is general agreement on some of the basic concepts of thunderstorm electrification. Electrification can be by the triboelectric effect as a result of ion transfer between colliding bodies. Uncharged
column3: colliding water-drops can become charged because of charge transfer between them (as aqueous ions) in an electric field as would exist in a thunder cloud.[4] The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F); see Figure 1. In that area
column4: the combination of temperature and rapid upward air movement produces a mixture of super-cooled cloud droplets (small water droplets below freezing)
column6: and graupel (soft hail). The updraft carries the super-cooled cloud droplets and very small ice crystals upward. At the same time
column8: which is considerably larger and denser
column9: tends to fall or be suspended in the rising air.[5]

column1: (Figure 2) When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged.

column1: The differences in the movement of the precipitation cause collisions to occur. When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged; see Figure 2. The updraft carries the positively charged ice crystals upward toward the top of the storm cloud. The larger and denser graupel is either suspended in the middle of the thunderstorm cloud or falls toward the lower part of the storm.[5]

column1: The upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to the lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.
The result is that the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.[5]

The upward motions within the storm and winds at higher levels in the atmosphere tend to cause the small ice crystals (and positive charge) in the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud to spread out horizontally some distance from the thunderstorm cloud base. This part of the thunderstorm cloud is called the anvil. While this is the main charging process for the thunderstorm cloud
column2: some of these charges can be redistributed by air movements within the storm (updrafts and downdrafts). In addition
column3: there is a small but important positive charge buildup near the bottom of the thunderstorm cloud due to the precipitation and warmer temperatures.[5]

column1: The induced separation of charge in pure liquid water has been known since the 1840s as has the electrification of pure liquid water by the tribo-electric effect.[6]

William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) demonstrated that charge separation in water occurs in the usual electric fields at the earth's surface and developed a continuous electric field measuring device using that knowledge.[7]

The physical separation of charge into different regions using liquid water was demonstrated by Kelvin with the Kelvin water dropper. The most likely charge-carrying species were considered to be the aqueous hydrogen ion and the aqueous hydroxide ion.[8]
The electrical charging of solid water ice has also been considered. The charged species were again considered to be the hydrogen ion and the hydroxide ion.[9][10]
An electron is not stable in liquid water with respect to a hydroxide ion plus dissolved hydrogen for the time scales involved in thunder storms.[11]

The charge carrier in lightning is mainly electrons in a plasma.[12] The process of going from charge as ions (positive hydrogen ion and negative hydroxide ion) associated with liquid water or solid water to charge as electrons associated with lightning must involve some form of electro-chemistry
column3: the oxidation and/or the reduction of chemical species.[13] As hydroxide functions as a base and carbon dioxide is an acidic gas
column4: it is possible that charged water clouds in which the negative charge is in the form of the aqueous hydroxide ion
column5: interact with atmospheric carbon dioxide to form aqueous carbonate ions and aqueous hydrogen carbonate ions.

column3: a typical thunderstorm produces three or more strikes to the Earth per minute.[15] Lightning primarily occurs when warm air is mixed with colder air masses
column4: [16] resulting in atmospheric disturbances necessary for polarizing the atmosphere.[citation needed] However
column5: it can also occur during dust storms

column1: In a process not well understood

column4: is initiated between oppositely-charged regions in a thundercloud. Leaders are electrically conductive channels of ionized gas that propagate through

column10: negative and some positive leaders travel in a discontinuous fashion
column11: in a process called "stepping". The resulting jerky movement of the leaders can be readily observed in slow-motion videos of lightning flashes.

column3: a bidirectional leader initiates between the main negative and lower positive charge regions in a thundercloud. The weaker positive charge region is filled quickly by the negative leader which then propagates toward the inductively-charged ground.

As these relativistic electrons collide and ionize neutral air molecules

Scientists fired ultra-fast pulses from an extremely powerful laser thus sending several terawatts into the clouds to call down electrical discharges in storm clouds over the region. The laser beams sent from the laser make channels of ionized molecules known as filaments. Before the lightning strikes earth
column4: the filaments lead electricity through the clouds
column5: playing the role of lightning rods. Researchers generated filaments that lived a period too short to trigger a real lightning strike. Nevertheless
column6: a boost in electrical activity within the clouds was registered. According to the French and German scientists who ran the experiment
column7: the fast pulses sent from the laser will be able to provoke lightning strikes on demand.[141] Statistical analysis showed that their laser pulses indeed enhanced the electrical activity in the thundercloud where it was aimedin effect they generated small local discharges located at the position of the plasma channels.[142]

column1: Lightning-induced remanent magnetization (LIRM) mapped during a magnetic field gradient survey of an archaeological site located in Wyoming

The movement of electrical charges produces a magnetic field (see electromagnetism). The intense currents of a lightning discharge create a fleeting but very strong magnetic field. Where the lightning current path passes through rock
column3: or metal these materials can become permanently magnetized. This effect is known as lightning-induced remanent magnetism
column4: or LIRM. These currents follow the least resistive path
column5: often horizontally near the surface[143][144] but sometimes vertically
column8: or ground water offers a less resistive path.[145] One theory suggests that lodestones
column9: natural magnets encountered in ancient times

column1: Lightning-induced magnetic anomalies can be mapped in the ground
column2: [147][148] and analysis of magnetized materials can confirm lightning was the source of the magnetization[149] and provide an estimate of the peak current of the lightning discharge.[150]

column1: Research at the University of Innsbruck has found that magnetic fields generated by plasma may induce hallucinations in subjects located within 200m (660ft) of a severe lightning storm.[151]
Some high energy cosmic rays produced by supernovas as well as solar particles from the solar wind
column2: enter the atmosphere and electrify the air
column3: which may create pathways for lightning bolts.[152]

column1: Due to the low resolution of global climate models
column2: accurately representing lightning in these climate models is difficult
column3: largely due to their inability to simulate the convection and cloud ice imperative which are fundamental to lightning formation. Research from the Future Climate for Africa programme demonstrates that using a convection-permitting model over Africa can more accurately capture convective thunderstorms and the distribution of ice particles. This research indicates climate change may increase the total amount of lightning only slightly: the total number of lightning days per year decreases
column4: while more cloud ice and stronger convection leads to more lightning strikes occurring on days when lightning does occur.[153]

column1: A study from the University of Washington looked at lightning activity in the Arctic from 2010 to 2020. The ratio of Arctic summertime strokes was compared to total global strokes and was observed to be increasing with time
column2: indicating that the region is becoming more influenced by lightning. The fraction of strokes above 65 degrees north was found to be increasing linearly with the NOAA global temperature anomaly and grew by a factor of 3 as the anomaly increased from 0.65 to 0.95C [154]

column1: .mw-parser-output .excerpt-hat .mw-editsection-like{font-style:normal}These paragraphs are an excerpt from Paleolightning.[edit]
Paleolightning refers to the remnants of ancient lightning activity studied in fields such as historical geology
column3: and fulminology. Paleolightning provides tangible evidence for the study lightning activity in Earth's past and the roles lightning may have played in Earth's history. Some studies have speculated that lightning activity played a crucial role in the development of not only Earth's early atmosphere but also early life. Lightning
column5: has been found to produce biologically useful material through the oxidation and reduction of inorganic matter.[155] Research on the impact of lightning on Earth's atmosphere continues today
column6: especially with regard to feedback mechanisms of lightning-produced nitrate compounds on atmospheric composition and global average temperatures.[156]

column1: Detecting lightning activity in the geologic record can be difficult
column2: given the instantaneous nature of lightning strikes in general. However
column3: fulgurite
column6: or irregular mineraloid that forms when lightning fuses soil
column11: or caliche is prevalent in electrically-active regions around the globe and provides evidence of not only past lightning activity
column12: but also patterns of convection.[157]  Since lightning channels carry an electric current to the ground
column13: lightning can produce magnetic fields as well. While lightning-magnetic anomalies can provide evidence of lightning activity in a region
column14: these anomalies are often problematic for those examining the magnetic record of rock types because they disguise the natural magnetic fields present.[158]

column2: lightning has been viewed as part of a deity or a deity in and of itself. These include the Greek god Zeus
column3: the Aztec god Tlaloc
column11: and the Shinto god Raijin.[159] In the traditional religion of the African Bantu tribes
column12: lightning is a sign of the ire of the gods. Verses in the Jewish religion and in Islam also ascribe supernatural importance to lightning. In Christianity
column13: the Second Coming of Jesus is compared to lightning.[Matthew 24:27][Luke 17:24]

column1: The expression "Lightning never strikes twice (in the same place)" is similar to "Opportunity never knocks twice" in the vein of a "once in a lifetime" opportunity
column3: something that is generally considered improbable. Lightning occurs frequently and more so in specific areas. Since various factors alter the probability of strikes at any given location
column4: repeat lightning strikes have a very low probability (but are not impossible).[160][161] Similarly
column5: "A bolt from the blue" refers to something totally unexpected
column6: and "A person being struck by lightning" is an imaginative or comedic metaphor for someone to experience a once in a lifetime
column9: similar to an epiphany or an enlightenment.

column2: the expression for "Love at first sight" is coup de foudre and colpo di fulmine
column3: respectively
column4: which literally translated means "lightning strike". Some European languages have a separate word for lightning which strikes the ground (as opposed to lightning in general); often it is a cognate of the English word "rays". The name of Australia's most celebrated thoroughbred horse
column6: derives from the shared Zhuang and Thai word for lightning.[162]

column1: Two lightning bolts pictured in the former coat of arms of the Yli-Ii municipality
The bolt of lightning in heraldry is called a thunderbolt and is shown as a zigzag with non-pointed ends. This symbol usually represents power and speed.
Some political parties use lightning flashes as a symbol of power
column2: such as the People's Action Party in Singapore
column3: the British Union of Fascists during the 1930s
column4: and the National States' Rights Party in the United States during the 1950s.[163] The Schutzstaffel
column5: the paramilitary wing of the Nazi Party
column6: used the Sig rune in their logo which symbolizes lightning. The German word Blitzkrieg
column8: was a major offensive strategy of the German army during World War II.

column1: The lightning bolt is a common insignia for military communications units throughout the world. A lightning bolt is also the NATO symbol for a signal asset.
The lightning bolt is used to represent the instantaneous communication capabilities of electrically powered telegraphs and radios. It was a commonly used motif in Art Deco design
column2: especially the zig-zag Art Deco design of the late 1920s.[164]

Lightning is a naturally occurring electrostatic discharge during which two electrically charged regions
column2: both in the atmosphere or with one on the ground
column3: temporarily neutralize themselves
column4: causing the instantaneous release of an average of one gigajoule of energy.[1][2][3] This discharge may produce a wide range of electromagnetic radiation
column5: from heat created by the rapid movement of electrons
column6: to brilliant flashes of visible light in the form of black-body radiation. Lightning causes thunder
column7: a sound from the shock wave which develops as gases in the vicinity of the discharge experience a sudden increase in pressure. Lightning occurs commonly during thunderstorms as well as other types of energetic weather systems
column8: but volcanic lightning can also occur during volcanic eruptions.

column1: The three main kinds of lightning are distinguished by where they occur: either inside a single thundercloud
column3: or between a cloud and the ground. Many other observational variants are recognized
column5: which can be seen from a great distance but not heard; dry lightning
column6: which can cause forest fires; and ball lightning

column1: Humans have deified lightning for millennia. Idiomatic expressions derived from lightning
column2: such as the English expression "bolt from the blue"
column3: are common across languages. The fear of lightning is called astraphobia.

column1: (Figure 1) The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where the air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F).
The details of the charging process are still being studied by scientists
column2: but there is general agreement on some of the basic concepts of thunderstorm electrification. Electrification can be by the triboelectric effect as a result of ion transfer between colliding bodies. Uncharged
column3: colliding water-drops can become charged because of charge transfer between them (as aqueous ions) in an electric field as would exist in a thunder cloud.[4] The main charging area in a thunderstorm occurs in the central part of the storm where air is moving upward rapidly (updraft) and temperatures range from 15 to 25C (5 to 13F); see Figure 1. In that area
column4: the combination of temperature and rapid upward air movement produces a mixture of super-cooled cloud droplets (small water droplets below freezing)
column6: and graupel (soft hail). The updraft carries the super-cooled cloud droplets and very small ice crystals upward. At the same time
column8: which is considerably larger and denser
column9: tends to fall or be suspended in the rising air.[5]

column1: (Figure 2) When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged.

column1: The differences in the movement of the precipitation cause collisions to occur. When the rising ice crystals collide with graupel
column2: the ice crystals become positively charged and the graupel becomes negatively charged; see Figure 2. The updraft carries the positively charged ice crystals upward toward the top of the storm cloud. The larger and denser graupel is either suspended in the middle of the thunderstorm cloud or falls toward the lower part of the storm.[5]

column1: The upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to the lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.
The result is that the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes positively charged while the middle to lower part of the thunderstorm cloud becomes negatively charged.[5]

The upward motions within the storm and winds at higher levels in the atmosphere tend to cause the small ice crystals (and positive charge) in the upper part of the thunderstorm cloud to spread out horizontally some distance from the thunderstorm cloud base. This part of the thunderstorm cloud is called the anvil. While this is the main charging process for the thunderstorm cloud
column2: some of these charges can be redistributed by air movements within the storm (updrafts and downdrafts). In addition
column3: there is a small but important positive charge buildup near the bottom of the thunderstorm cloud due to the precipitation and warmer temperatures.[5]

column1: The induced separation of charge in pure liquid water has been known since the 1840s as has the electrification of pure liquid water by the tribo-electric effect.[6]

William Thomson (Lord Kelvin) demonstrated that charge separation in water occurs in the usual electric fields at the earth's surface and developed a continuous electric field measuring device using that knowledge.[7]

The physical separation of charge into different regions using liquid water was demonstrated by Kelvin with the Kelvin water dropper. The most likely charge-carrying species were considered to be the aqueous hydrogen ion and the aqueous hydroxide ion.[8]
The electrical charging of solid water ice has also been considered. The charged species were again considered to be the hydrogen ion and the hydroxide ion.[9][10]
An electron is not stable in liquid water with respect to a hydroxide ion plus dissolved hydrogen for the time scales involved in thunder storms.[11]

The charge carrier in lightning is mainly electrons in a plasma.[12] The process of going from charge as ions (positive hydrogen ion and negative hydroxide ion) associated with liquid water or solid water to charge as electrons associated with lightning must involve some form of electro-chemistry
column3: the oxidation and/or the reduction of chemical species.[13] As hydroxide functions as a base and carbon dioxide is an acidic gas
column4: it is possible that charged water clouds in which the negative charge is in the form of the aqueous hydroxide ion
column5: interact with atmospheric carbon dioxide to form aqueous carbonate ions and aqueous hydrogen carbonate ions.
